Messages.Author: Adela Bravo Sauras
Messages.Content: Hello everyone,  As we discussed in class, the presentations on Thursday will be a total of 20 minutes, so please try to keep your part to a maximum of 7 minutes. They will be done using the beamer and from your laptops.   Additionally, if they are not needed for the presentation, you need to print your panels to hang on Thursday, following the distributed layout. If it is not possible to stick to the layout exactly, be flexible so that they can be placed on the wall for the final exhibition. The same goes for the A4 layout, which we will print on Thursday with what you send us.  I will ask Alexander if it is possible to have a screen or beamer on Thursday and Friday for our exhibition, so that those groups requiring it for videos, as communicated to me today, can use it. Best regards and lots of energy for this final push.  Adela

On Thursday, Jan Kampshoff, a guest professor from the department, will join us, and on Friday, Elena Lamata and Alejandro Guijarro from Fundbüro will be with us. I recommend that your presentations, which will be projected on the wall, be as concise as possible to allow more time for discussion and feedback from the guest critics. Next week, on Thursday, July 11, we will not meet as I will be attending the final presentation of JZO, and on Friday, July 12, it will be our last meeting before the final presentation on Thursday, July 18.  For all subsequent presentations, the order will be as follows and will not change to avoid confusion and issues like last week:  - Group 1: 10:30-10:50 Melis, Dogu - Group 2: 10:50-11:10 Francesco, Riko, Joshua - Group 3: 11:10-11:30 Ece, Dogan, Beyza - Group 4: 11:30-11:50 Thalia, Artur - Group 5: 11:50-12:10 Luis Enrique, Hye-Sook - Group 6: 12:10-12:30 Antonia, Clara, Amarel - Group 7: 12:30-12:50 Yuki, Weinong, Emilio - Group 8: 12:50-13:10 Joel, Bridget - Group 9: 13:10-13:30 Jose Sinhue  I have been informed that your final submission of the portfolio, including improvements to the final projects based on the feedback from the final presentation, as well as the individual submissions A1, A2, and A3, will be due digitally on Friday, August 16. Discussions.Discussion_Name: New texts in the "Reading Material" folder

Messages.Author: Adela Bravo Sauras
Messages.Content: Hello everyone,  I have uploaded four texts to the "Reading Material" folder:  1. The Caring City: Health, Economy, and Environment by Izaskun Chinchilla Moreno. This book invites us to rethink architectural and urban models by prioritizing the public and civic dimensions of citizens' experiences, rather than the technical and formal knowledge sought by urban planners. It highlights how, after decades of industrialization, our cities have become productivity-oriented, often at the expense of non-productive activities like resting, accessing public toilets, drinking clean water without paying, or breathing unpolluted air. This focus on productivity has led to the neglect of the inhabitants' biological and subjective needs, turning this neglect into a cultural principle and political practice. "The Caring City" presents a broad range of alternatives that unify the economy, the environment, and the health of a diverse community.  2. Performance Spaces and Spatial Performativity: Theatre has left the building by Dorita Hannah. This chapter examines the evolution of theatrical space, from the enduring monuments of the 19th century, through the experimental sites of the 20th century, to the ephemeral and transitory locations of the 21st century. In this context, a deliberate lack of permanent home reinforces the community itself as a house. A "death" of enduring forms of theatre architecture is suggested, allowing for the emergence of more dynamic spatialities in contemporary European venues that offer alternatives to the traditional models of proscenium stage and black box studio. 3. Architecture and Disjunction and the article "Architecture and Events" both by Bernard Tschumi   I hope you find these texts interesting and useful. Best regards,   Adela

Discussions.Discussion_Name: Updates, Meeting Details, PIV Case Studies

Messages.Author: Adela Bravo Sauras
Messages.Content: Hello everyone,  I am continuously updating the Excel list containing the PIV cases with some data. When you find the number of people your theaters can accommodate or the basic data in the list, please fill it in this Excel sheet, sorted by the year of completion.  I have responded to all the emails with questions. Tomorrow, I will be attending the IFA PhD Day at the institute, so I won’t be able to respond to any emails with queries until then. We will meet directly this Thursday at 10 am in the inner courtyard of Sophiensäle: [Google Maps link](https://maps.app.goo.gl/7a3HFxT5aFV3jeZK7). At 1 pm, there will be a talk by Jan Kampshoff, who is the guest professor of our department and will be present at the final presentation of your projects in July.  Please upload the material related to all exercises to the corresponding folders so that I can continue providing feedback.  I have added a text to the Reading Material folder: Özel, Mehmet Kerem, Performativity of Theatre Architecture, 2017, Online Journal of Art and Design, and Dwyre, Cathryn, and Perry, Chris, "Expanded Fields: Architecture/Landscape/Performance", PAJ 109. These can be very helpful for some of the PIV cases and, in general, for reflecting on spaces that meet the flexibility required by contemporary projects. I wanted to extract the conclusion from the first text in this message because I think it can be a great inspiration for your design projects:  “Ultimately, what if, not within the delimitations of a conventional architectural inner space as given examples up to this point, but the building itself as a whole would be the physical manifestation of performativity? Once more, a collaboration between a theatre person and an architect, between Joan Littlewood and Cedric Price, gave a perfect answer to this question: The Fun Palace (1964) is an open, extendable overall structure with no fixed ground plan (Figure 12).” (p.80, Özel, Mehmet Kerem, Performativity of Theatre Architecture, 2017, Online Journal of Art and Design)  “Avant-garde theatre producer Joan Littlewood’s dream was to create a new kind of theatre of pure performativity and interaction (Mathews 2005, 75). Price’s solution was an improvisational architecture endlessly in the process of construction, dismantling, and reassembly with infinite variation and flexibility (Mathews 2005, 74). As Stanley Mathews (2005, 79) explains, the Fun Palace was “not a static and solid ‘building’, but a new kind of active and dynamic architecture which would permit multiple uses and which would constantly adapt to change. It would be a network of multiple events, a space of oscillation between incongruous activities simultaneously played out like some Dada performance. Spaces should be endlessly varied in size, shape, lighting, and accessibility.” Another important characteristic of the Fun Palace is that “since [its] program would be ad hoc, determined by the users, its behavior would be unstable, indeterminate, and unknowable in advance” (Mathews 2005, 81).” (p.80, Özel, Mehmet Kerem, Performativity of Theatre Architecture, 2017, Online Journal of Art and Design)  CONCLUSION: As can be noticed, most of the revolutionary theatre projects discussed in the context of performativity are unbuilt architecture. In this sense, rereading and reinterpreting black box type theatre architecture from a performative perspective could be stimulating for the future of theater architecture. Peter Brook (1968, 65), who stated that he had many abortive discussions with architects building new theatres, asks in his seminal book “The Empty Space”: “The science of theatre-building must come from studying what it is that brings about the most vivid relationship between people – and is this best served by asymmetry, even by disorder? If so, what can be the rule of disorder?” The clue to the answer to Brook’s question may be the performativity of architecture in the theatrical space among the performances of the actors and of the spectators.” (p.81, Özel, Mehmet Kerem, Performativity of Theatre Architecture, 2017, Online Journal of Art and Design) *Brook, P. (1968). The Empty Space. New York: Touchstone.

Discussions.Discussion_Name: 21.05.24_Updates and Resources for Upcoming Assignments

Messages.Author: Adela Bravo Sauras
Messages.Content: ### Subject: Important Updates and Resources for Upcoming Assignments  Hello everyone,  In the ISIS literature folder, you will find many documents that might interest you. The book by Juliane Rebentisch on aesthetics in installation art is now available there, and it includes a chapter specifically dedicated to theatricality in installation works.  Some of you may not have received a response to the email I sent with you copied to the architects or creators from whom we are still missing plans. Enorme Studio and EEEstudio have already sent everything they have, and Zuloark will respond next week.  Regarding the PIV assignment, the difference between Cyan Blue and Magenta colored projects is not really clear. According to my email, both of these colors mean that we are required to find images, plans, and draw a scheme of the type of theater. Simply put, some projects already have more information in the catalog shared with you, so there is less work to be done. Here, as I mentioned before, is the information already gathered from the PIV theater building catalog. Here is the link once again: [PIV Theater Building Catalog](https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1YWmq-SFYgYmHhGvaol_GO3YR0yzri3vG).  For speculative or unrealized projects, it is best to always evaluate their characteristics as if they had been built.  In A2, when analyzing the building's deficiencies or sustainability issues, it is possible to do so from the perspective of materials and functional areas of the design. If you cannot fit all the information into one design, create more than one drawing. The shared templates for Exercise A2 are a model for you to choose which best suits the information you want to discuss. You can make variations in this template. There is no page limit, so use as many as you need. The final format is A3, and the requirement is to follow those layouts.  In section 5: “5. Type of Context offered by the Building. Can a project be carried out on the stage? Is there a black box theater? What other possibilities are there? In this section, you should analyze the building‘s deficiencies or issues in adapting to contemporary theater and other types of events. We‘re also interested in your study of previous projects that have posed a challenge to the architectural configuration of the theater,” you should not only write a text about these aspects. You can (and should) use diagrams or drawings on the plans to illustrate your ideas on these topics. Although possible theatricalities may have already been indicated in section 4, you can analyze the spaces and their characteristics that are not directly on the stage but where one of the projects from our extensive list of analyzed projects could take place offstage. If you want to combine tasks 4 and 5, you can do so without any problem.  **Type of Context Offered by the Building:** - Describe the surroundings and physical characteristics of the building. - Assess whether the building has adaptable spaces for different types of theatrical productions and events.  **Existence of a Black Box Theater:** - Verify if the building includes a black box theater. - Explore and describe other possibilities the building may offer for events and theatrical productions, such as outdoor spaces, multipurpose rooms, etc.  **Analysis of Building Deficiencies or Issues:** - Identify and analyze the building’s deficiencies or issues in adapting to contemporary theater and other types of events. - Evaluate how these deficiencies might affect the functionality and flexibility of the building for hosting modern productions.  **Study of Previous Projects:** - Investigate and study previous projects that have faced challenges with the architectural configuration of the theater. - Analyze how these projects addressed and overcame the challenges presented by the building’s design.  This exercise requires an analytical and detailed approach, using concrete examples and case studies to illustrate the points mentioned. The goal is to understand how the building can (or cannot) adapt to the needs of contemporary theater and what improvements might be implemented.  The buildings may correspond to one or several theatrical typologies. If needed, use the floor plans and sections to analyze the building's usage, not just to identify the types of stages they offer. After all, some of you may carry out projects in these buildings, and it is interesting to see how access and basic functions of these floors work.  The canceled Basurama talk will be rescheduled, although we do not yet know the date. This week, there are two scheduled talks: one by Isla Architects via Zoom at 13:30, and an in-person talk by Dr. Thea Brejzek, Professor of Spatial Theory at the School of Architecture at the University of Technology, Sydney, and a member of the Scientific Advisory Board of the Bauhaus Foundation Dessau.  As I mentioned, on Friday, May 31st, we will present the PIV assignments. On Friday, June 7th, you will present your individual ideas so we can form work groups for the project. Starting Thursday, June 13th, all Thursdays and Fridays will be dedicated to project work and desk crits. One of your classmates would like to give a presentation on a project they participated in that relates to the course topics. I think it would be interesting to set a date for those who want to give more extensive presentations starting from that date. I propose Friday, June 14th for this purpose.  Best regards Adela

Discussions.Discussion_Name: PIV CLARIFICATION

Messages.Author: Adela Bravo Sauras
Messages.Content: Hello everyone,  For the PIV exercise, as previously announced, you are required to use the A01a exercise layout available in this folder for case studies focusing on performances or according to the following categories from the Excel "List of Characteristics":  1. **THEATRE PROJECTS - ON THEATRE STAGES:** Involving a built installation that alters the use of the theatre, with actors, where both actors and spectators share the space. 2. **THEATRE PROJECTS - INSIDE THEATRE BUILDINGS** (not on stage or the stage area in Black Box situations): Featuring a built installation that changes the traditional appearance of theatres, with actors, where actors and spectators share the space. 3. **THEATRE PROJECTS - OUTSIDE THEATRE BUILDINGS:** Entailing something built (not on a theatre stage or within theatre buildings), with actors, where actors and spectators share the space.  **No Actors, All Visitors Share the Space:** 4. **THEATRE PROJECTS - ON THEATRE STAGES:** With a built installation that changes theatre use, without actors. 5. **THEATRE PROJECTS - OUTSIDE THEATRE BUILDINGS:** Having something built (not on a theatre stage or in theatre buildings), without actors, where spectators can move freely throughout the entire space. 6. **PERFORMANCES FROM ARCHITECTS:** Projects outside theatre buildings that include a physically built element, without actors, where visitors can move freely throughout the entire space. 7. **INSTALLATIONS FROM ARTISTS (with a performative and built element):** Projects outside theatre buildings, with actors, where visitors can move freely throughout the entire space. 8. **INSTALLATIONS FROM ARTISTS (with a performative and built element):** Projects outside theatre buildings, without actors, where visitors can move freely throughout the entire space. 9. **PROJECTS FROM ARCHITECTS with a performative element and a built element:** Including historical projects (before the 70s) where visitors can freely move throughout the entire space.  **Participants Do Not Share Space:** 10. **THEATRE PROJECTS - ON THEATRE STAGES:** With a built installation that changes the use of theatre, with actors, where actors and spectators do not share space. 11. **THEATRE PROJECTS - OUTSIDE THEATRE BUILDINGS:** Featuring a built installation that changes the use of theatre, with actors, where actors and spectators do not share space.  For those assigned a "building" project, a very simple layout is also uploaded in the PIV folder. You only need to select the type of theatre and fill in the corresponding section. For most buildings, existing floor plans, section images, and photographs are sufficient, and redrawing them is unnecessary. Thus, those working on this simpler scheme will receive another five buildings for each of these straightforward case studies to ensure equity with others who analyze the device, context, accessibility, and theatricality, and typically write a descriptive text. These categories include: 16. **ARCHITECTURE PROJECTS:** That deal with community, gathering, pavilions (something built, no performance). 17. **BUILT STRUCTURES THAT COULD HOST PERFORMANCES BUT ARE NOT MAINLY CONCEIVED FOR THEATRE.** 18. **THEATRE AND EVENT BUILDINGS.**  You will receive the full list this week, but you can start on the initial sheets and raise any questions if needed. Thank you, and please proceed accordingly.

Messages.Author: Adela Bravo Sauras
Messages.Content: Hello everyone, thank you for today's intense and productive presentation session. Please email me your work if you couldn't upload it to the platform's folder. In the upcoming weeks, I will provide brief individual feedback on your A1a+b+c assignments via email, and you can make adjustments to improve your work. A new folder for final submissions will be created on the platform next week (feel free to send me your drafts via email before then).   Please remember not to change the layout colors! Messages.Content: Hello everyone,  I have responded to all emails with questions. If I haven't replied to any of you, please send me an email at adelabravo@gmail.com. There are few of you who are active in the Excel document listing the project characteristics. Remember that this is part of the Friday submission and will help you describe the characteristics paragraph and identify the project's key points.  A general clarification: a "characteristic" refers to a distinguishing feature or quality of something, while a "dispositive" typically refers to a mechanism, device, or system designed to achieve a specific purpose or goal. In simpler terms, characteristics describe what something is like, while dispositives are tools or instruments used to bring about certain outcomes.  Best regards.

Messages.Author: Adela Bravo Sauras
Messages.Content: Hello everyone, Until Friday, the 10th in the morning, which is the submission deadline, you can email me with any questions you may have, and I'll try to respond as soon as possible. Please send the emails to adelabravo@gmail.com so that I can read them from home as well. Don't forget that you need to fill in the crosses, dashes, or zeros in the Excel sheet with the characteristics for the projects. I've shared the Excel file via email so that we can all work on the same document. Completing this exercise might be tedious, but it provides you with insights into how different aspects of the project function.  For some characteristics, your projects may not exactly match what is described in the Excel sheet. That's why you can write down any specificities or doubts in the left column that make your project not fit exactly. This will make the document very long, but don't worry, it's okay. It's clearer to read your comments later than to only have dashes without understanding the doubts. For the description of the devices in the first 3 cases A01a and A01b, there isn't enough space in the initial layout, so now you have a page uploaded for everyone to write more extensively about the devices. The A2 exercise of site analysis in teams is already uploaded to the platform, although it starts on Friday the 10th in the afternoon. It has a layout as an example that you can use flexibly depending on how much text you have for each section or the size of the images. The A01c exercise has its layout uploaded to the folder on the A01c platform. As you can see, for the projects where you only need to analyze the device, you have to draw the project's floor plan and general axonometric, and then the floor plan and axonometric of the device only. On Friday the 10th, we will have a presentation in class where each of you can talk about your analyzed projects. Discussions.Discussion_Name: Guidelines and Clarifications for Exercise A01a and A01b

Messages.Author: Adela Bravo Sauras
Messages.Content: Hello everyone, Only 11 people have uploaded exercise A01a to the ISIS folder. Please email me your work at adelabravo@gmail.com if you want me to provide feedback, or bring them to class this Thursday so we can review them. It would be good to bring exercise A01b to class this Thursday so we can go over it and address any questions. We'll have more time since the Enorme talk has been canceled.  Some clarifications about the exercise: PLANT AND AXONOMETRIC  The initial plant and axonometric always refer to the entirety of the project. In this case, you only need to make modifications to the plant and axonometric already provided to adapt them to the corresponding venue. For example, the Municipal Theater in My hands. My mothers. The axonometric and plant of the device must indicate its location within the project to avoid ambiguity. If the device is very small, consider including two images to show a zoomed-in view. Since the layout space is limited, if details appear too small, colleagues can refer to the original file for a closer look if the PDF appears crowded.  DEVICES  When naming devices, the goal is not to be poetic or creative with words, but to describe them scientifically—what they are, their function, contribution, etc. This approach aims for regulatory and design details irrespective of project themes.  What procedures occur in the project that differentiate it from a traditional theatrical event? How do spectators navigate differently, or what distinguishes these mechanisms from traditional theater? For example, if curtains are part of the project, how are they utilized?  Who can access the project and how? What boundaries are transgressed by doing so? Is access feasible for everyone? How can this idea be expressed physically for another author to use in a different thematic context?  What does it entail for spectators to view elements (objects, people, etc.) on stage as presented, and in the presented order, even in different modalities and their sequence?  CONTEXT  The context diagram comes first, followed by accessibility. Any template errors were addressed in the previous announcement. Accessibility and theatricality concern the entire project, not just your chosen device.  You can be more specific with your drawings, utilizing theater blueprints to depict projects and visitor access routes from the street. In the project My hands. My mothers., though the shared diagrams belong to the Institut für Angewandte Theaterwissenschaft in Giessen, adapting them for the Teatro Municipal de Coslada is feasible.  ACCESSIBILITY  In the accessibility scheme, focus on the entire project, including how your device interacts with accessibility. Indicate what is outside and inside, as well as intermediary positions. Different areas within the project may have varying degrees of accessibility. Can visitors access all areas at any time? Are all positions open to everyone? How close can visitors get to elements?  If the legend provided for theatricality seems inadequate, feel free to adjust it while adhering to the color palette. Include it in the drawing for clarity. A legend aids specificity in your drawings, conveying ideas visually and reducing reliance on text.  Theatricality pertains to the entire project with its different areas. As changes occur based on scene or sequence, aim to showcase as many theatrical elements as possible. Additional plants may be necessary, but if they don't fit well due to space constraints, colleagues can refer to the original file for details.  Best Adela

Messages.Content: Hello everyone,  We were informed this morning that Enorme Studio's talk scheduled for this Thursday has been canceled as they will be traveling to Japan.  In the drive folder containing information on theatrical buildings, I have also uploaded the floor plans of the Sophiensäle. Additionally, here is a video tour of the space for your convenience: [https://sophiensaele.com/de/seite/barrierefreiheit#barrierefreiheit_360_videotour](https://sophiensaele.com/de/seite/barrierefreiheit#barrierefreiheit_360_videotour)  The project "Love Fiction" also took place at the Sophiensäle in 2016, as you can see here: [https://sophiensaele.com/en/stueck/the-agency-love-fiction](https://sophiensaele.com/en/stueck/the-agency-love-fiction) I have shared a folder with the students who are studying this project. https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1diHvuZBfiKQbjf48Or9j_3MtiRf_E2AG?usp=share_link I have also shared some plans from Teatro Municipal Coslada for the students studying My hands. My mothers per email. I have uploaded three texts to the 'Reading Material' folder. They are: "Theatrale Übergangsräume: Black Box, White Cube und Stadtraum als Orte der Aufführung" by Annett Lang, which is in German but can be translated with AI and is very relevant if you are studying the differences between black box spaces, white cubes, and urban spaces as venues for theatrical performances.  Also, I've uploaded a text by Elena Tavani titled "Theatricality in Installation Artworks: An Overview." Lastly, another text by Lenka Nováková titled "The Scenographic Unfolding: Performance of Immersive, Interactive, and Participatory Environments." I have Juliane Rebentisch's excellent book "Aesthetics of Installation Art" in the department but haven’t been able to scan it yet. The chapter on theatricality from pages 21 to 73 is particularly relevant, although the entire book would be very beneficial for us.  I was pleased to see some students at the "RADICAL PLAYGROUNDS: Ein Kunstparcours am Gropius Bau" on Saturday and Sunday. I highly recommend it to everyone as the theme is very much related to our research. best Adela

Discussions.Discussion_Name: Feedback and Instructions for Project Submissions

Messages.Author: Adela Bravo Sauras
Messages.Content: Dear all,  I have sent feedback via email to the projects that were submitted by this morning. For the rest, please upload them by this Friday, April 26th, so I can provide feedback. There are some recurring aspects that I want to address: you should give a name to the device you identify, and in the text, you should describe exactly what that element does, how its construction or installation influences how the project is used, or how participants can perceive it, or how they can gather around it. Why does it help to facilitate interaction between actors and spectators in a special way? How would the project function differently if this element were not present? Try to be as specific as possible. If you need more space to express yourselves, you can send the texts via email and write a summary in the layout.  In the theatricality diagrams, if the performance has different stages, it would be helpful if you indicate the stage you are analyzing. It would be even better if you could either mark several phases on the same plane or create smaller plans and highlight the changes in theatricality.  In the context plans, it would be good to indicate at least a couple of streets outside the building and where the project site is located within the building. Provide your own legends to help us understand the drawings if necessary.  Regarding accessibility, you can reflect more deeply than just indicating an arrow. How accessible are the spaces within the installation and the installation itself? Is the project porous or very closed? Is it architecture that provides access or not to the visitor compared to others? What are you basing your answers on to these questions?  Specifically in the Meat project, the project was actually created by Theda Bo Nilsson, as the author changed her name. Please update this information.  Regarding the floor plan, the project was located inside the Studio, which is not the main building of the Schaubühne but rather the building opposite, which functions as a black box theater. There is an error in the plan because although there is an opening, access to that hallway was only possible through the west opening, so you can draw a door to close the other opening if you wish. best Adela

Discussions.Discussion_Name: Updates on Project Analysis and Upcoming Sessions

Messages.Author: Adela Bravo Sauras
Messages.Content: Dear students,  We don't have the 3D documents of the axonometrics for the four examples. Nor do we have the examples drawn within the theater building floor plans in DWG format.  Each one of you ONLY has to analyze one of the projects, not all four.  I repeat, tomorrow, Wednesday, you don't have to submit the complete analysis exercise of the first case study at 9 am if you haven't completed it. But by submitting it, you have the opportunity to receive my opinion or to write any doubts to me in a separate email.  This Thursday, April 25th, from 10-12, there will be an input session led by me regarding the remaining case studies for this first exercise, along with a brief theoretical input. I have divided the case studies which I will provide in class so that each student can work on the tasks you have done with the first 4 case studies. Then, at 12, there will be a presentation by Wismar students for you via Zoom.  This Friday, April 26th, at 11:45, there will be a guided tour of the theater that Wismar students will be studying for their projects, and you are invited if you wish to attend. The address is Alter Garten, 2, 19055, Schwerin, Mecklenburg State Theatre (with Wismar students). It takes 2 hours and 45 minutes from the architecture building, so you would need to leave here at 8:30. If you plan to attend, please write to Rubén Jódar (ruben.jodar@hs-wismar.de) so he can include you. https://maps.app.goo.gl/jy7a2sTXQWgD9BNy8 I will not be attending the visit and will remain at the TU in case anyone has doubts or wants to have a desk critique (those interested, please write to me on Thursday after class to create a schedule for Friday).  Floor plan context Information You only need to indicate the approximate situation of the project inside the buildings, if it is placed on the stage or inside a space that is a black box situation, the entrance and exit paths from the street, and those general access details.  You have information about the theatre buildings Schaubühne and Volksbühne in a drive folder: https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1EI-UIPWdZpluWE7nTCodmtc6VSRIKcjS?usp=sharing  Meat: The information to perform the floor plan context is that the Meat project was located inside the Schaubühne Studio, which is situated in front of the main building. Its entrance is through number 155, and the floor plan is in DWG in the folder with information about the theaters (Studio Grundriss): https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1EI-UIPWdZpluWE7nTCodmtc6VSRIKcjS?usp=sharingThe entrance corridor corresponds to the wall of the Studio's limit, and the services are already outside the project. You only need to indicate the approximate situation of the project inside the studio, the entrance and exit paths from the street, and those general access details.  In the cases we don't have plans from the buildings please check in google earth and make a simplification from the buildings: Mousonturm theatre in Frankfurt for Love Fiction that took place on the second floor:  https://www.mousonturm.de/  Teatro Municipal Coslada en Madrid https://www.redescena.net/escenario/3123/teatro-municipal-de-coslada/)  for My hands.My mothers that took place on stage at that venue (this project also happened inside other venues like Teatro Pradillo in Madrid, Instituto Cervantes in Madrid or at the Probebühne at the Institut for Angewandte Theaterwissenschaft in Giessen in Germany but the first venue is the best one. Answers added 15:30: The final submission of Task 1 is next Thursday, May 2nd. Whether a presentation will be held is still to be confirmed, depending on the time required by the visit and the talk scheduled for next week.  The project title is as given by the authors: "Meat, Coming Society, My hands. My mother's, and Love Fiction"; you don't need to create a new title. If you have a good idea for a subtitle, you can add it in the description.  The exercise for next week will also be individual. The analyses for this week and next are not relevant for the formation of the groups that will be formed later on.  The project's location remains the same; you don't have to think of a new one. This is still an analysis, not a new design. You should be creative or simply thorough in understanding the project, scrutinizing its details.  I hope I have answered all the questions. If you have more please do not hesitate to contact me. best Adela

Discussions.Discussion_Name: Important Reminder: Enrollment Information and MOSES Registration + Information about the task A01a

Messages.Author: Adela Bravo Sauras
Messages.Content: Dear students, Four of you have not provided information regarding your enrollment and major, nor have you submitted the confidentiality document. I kindly request that you do so as soon as possible. ALL OF YOU also need to be registered in MOSES, so please ensure this is completed. You are all already in the Information System for Instructors and Students, so communication will be conducted through this channel. Additionally, please inform me via email whether you intend to take the PIV course, so that I have the final list of students (even if you filled out this information in class, please confirm via email to ensure accuracy).  I've received inquiries regarding the documents, linking of links, and required fonts to the InDesign file. For these types of questions, please contact our tutor Alexander Binn at binn@campus.tu-berlin.de. The texts written in the templates are obviously placeholders and you should replace them with texts written by yourselves. You only need to keep the headings clear (PROJECT TITLE, CHARACTERISTICS, DEVICE, THEATRICALITY, CONTEXT, ACCESSIBILITY). Synonyms for the word DEVICE are "device", "tool", "appliance", "instrument", "gadget", 'machinery', 'apparatus', 'construction', or 'deployment'. You have received a dossier for each project via email, containing a lot of information, plans, photographs, scripts, but some of you want more information. For those studying the MEAT project, I have shared a Google Drive folder called 01B_DOCUMENTATION: [https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1OISiD7tz2nO3jrYWGNYXEv508-vfz1SA?usp=share_link]. For those studying the COMING SOCIETY project, there is another folder: [https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1_u4_vay34PYC6i9tpmT_Zat-EApOT8Nn?usp=share_link]. Those studying MY HANDS. MY MOTHERS have received an email with links to videos. And those studying LOVE FICTION have a folder: [https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1ODrbK346H0WMq8AyfS3cnLk7MEOiikx0?usp=share_link]. The final deadline to complete this exercise is not this Wednesday, April 24th, but Thursday, May 2nd of next week. However, you will receive more case studies this week, and I would strongly recommend that you finish these case studies by the end of this week to avoid accumulating work. Thank you very much. Best regards. Adela

Tomorrow, I will explain some case studies and introduce a concept necessary for the first exercise. For those who, exceptionally, cannot attend in person tomorrow, please write to me so you can attend via Zoom. On Friday, we will have our first talk. For our first ToBuildTalk this semester, we welcome Veronica Zaripova at 10:30 in the same classroom.
